docs.lead_paragraph: Missouri Gov. Jay Nixon vetoed legislation Monday that would have limited who could work in the state as a health insurance guide and blamed a national conservative group for injecting an error into the model legislation.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Wisconsin senator on Monday argued that his lawsuit challenging rules that call for congressional members and their employees to seek government-subsidized health insurance through small-business exchanges should be allowed to move forward.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a story July 7 about the United Nations recognizing gay marriage for its staff members, The Associated Press, relying on information from the U.N., reported erroneously that the new policy affected only employees of the U.N. Secretariat. The policy applies to all U.N. employees, including those who work at separate agencies and programs such as UNICEF and UNESCO.

headline.main: What's News in Washington: Immigration Fireworks

docs.abstract: Congress is set to return to work after its midsummer recess. While little legislation is expected to pass before the midterm elections in November, immigration is expected to remain the rhetorical focus on Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: The excitement of acceptance into that dream college has passed. The first day of classes is still weeks away. But the resources provided by high school teachers and computer labs are no longer available for recent graduates.

docs.lead_paragraph: The North End, which has both glorious homes and some of the city’s harshest blight, captures both the hope and challenge of the mayor’s pledge to improve Detroit.

headline.seo: Mayor Mike Duggan’s Pledges Echo in Detroit’s North End
headline.main: Testing Ground for a New Detroit
headline.print_headline: Testing Ground for a New Detroit

docs.abstract: Detroit's North End, which has both glorious homes and some of the city’s harshest blight, captures both the hope and challenge of Mayor Mike Duggan's pledge to improve the bankrupt city; tracking what happens in the neighborhood, area undergoing change, in 2014 and 2015 will tell a lot about whether Detroit, with nearly 690,000 residents, can rebuild (Series: Ruin and Renewal).
docs.snippet: The North End, which has both glorious homes and some of the city’s harshest blight, captures both the hope and challenge of the mayor’s pledge to improve Detroit.

byline.contributor: Monica Davey contributed reporting and Alain Delaquérière contributed research.
